prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HDO absorption toward AS209, AS205(A)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations targeting the 1(1,1)-0(0,0) transition of HDO at 893.6 GHz in absorption using sub-mm disks as background continuum sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Foreground HDO absorption lines are expected to consist of a single component with FWHM of about 1 km/s. The spectral resolution of 0.164 km/s ensures that the absorption line will be well sampled, even in the case where we bin in the spectral direction (0.34 km/s resolution) to improve RMS sensitivity if necessary.

The sub-millimeter disks that we are using as background sources tend to be about 3-4 arcsec in diameter, but emission at 1.3mm is strongly centrally peaked with gaussian FWHM typically 1-1.5 arcsec. In order to guarantee sufficient background continuum flux for our absorption line experiment, we request 2.8 arcsec as the largest angular scale. The angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec is chosen given the array configurations where the requested largest angular scale is achievable. Additionally, 0.2 arcsec resolution enables the study of about 30 AU size scales in the background disks for the secondary goals of our proposal.

For this absorption line experiment we are targeting continuum level signal-to-noise ratios (quoted as spectral dynamic range by the AOT) of about 20, such that 25% deep absorption features are detected at 5 times the RMS sensitivity level. Given this goal, peak line flux densities in the Field Setup are reported as 0.25 times the peak continuum flux densities. The achieved continuum level S/N depends on the flux of the background source at 893 GHz, which is estimated in the "source properties" field from reported 350 micron fluxes or spectral energy distributions (SED). An RMS level of 141 mJy will give continuum level S/N of about 33 for AS 205A and about 21 for AS 209. We can also bin channels to 0.33 km/s resolution to reduce the RMS to 100 mJy, and increase continuum level S/N to about 47 for AS 205A and 30 for AS 209 to search for weaker absorption features.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HDO absorption toward DoAr25, SR24(S), GSS 39
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations targeting the 1(1,1)-0(0,0) transition of HDO at 893.6 GHz in absorption using sub-mm disks as background continuum sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Foreground HDO absorption lines are expected to consist of a single component with FWHM of about 1 km/s. The spectral resolution of 0.164 km/s ensures that the absorption line will be well sampled, even in the case where we bin in the spectral direction (0.34 km/s resolution) to improve RMS sensitivity if necessary.

The sub-millimeter disks that we are using as background sources tend to be about 3-4 arcsec in diameter, but emission at 1.3mm is strongly centrally peaked with gaussian FWHM typically 1-1.5 arcsec. In order to guarantee sufficient background continuum flux for our absorption line experiment, we request 2.8 arcsec as the largest angular scale. The angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec is chosen given the array configurations where the requested largest angular scale is achievable. Additionally, 0.2 arcsec resolution enables the study of about 30 AU size scales in the background disks for the secondary goals of our proposal.

For this absorption line experiment we are targeting continuum level signal-to-noise ratios (quoted as spectral dynamic range by the AOT) of about 20, such that 25% deep absorption features are detected at 5 times the RMS sensitivity level. Given this goal, peak line flux densities in the Field Setup are reported as 0.25 times the peak continuum flux densities. The achieved continuum level S/N depends on the flux of the background source at 893 GHz, which is estimated in the "source properties" field from reported 350 micron fluxes or spectral energy distributions (SED). An RMS level of 90 mJy will give a continuum level S/N of about 21, 26, and 14 for DoAr25, GSS39, and SR24(S), respectively. We can also bin channels to 0.33 km/s resolution to reduce the RMS to 64 mJy, and increase continuum level S/N to about 29, 36, and 20 for DoAr25, GSS39, and SR24(S), respectively, to search for weaker absorption features.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HDO absorption toward SR21(A) and Elia 2-24
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observations targeting the 1(1,1)-0(0,0) transition of HDO at 893.6 GHz in absorption using sub-mm disks as background continuum sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Foreground HDO absorption lines are expected to consist of a single component with FWHM of about 1 km/s. The spectral resolution of 0.164 km/s ensures that the absorption line will be well sampled, even in the case where we bin in the spectral direction (0.34 km/s resolution) to improve RMS sensitivity if necessary.

The sub-millimeter disks that we are using as background sources tend to be about 3-4 arcsec in diameter, but emission at 1.3mm is strongly centrally peaked with gaussian FWHM typically 1-1.5 arcsec. In order to guarantee sufficient background continuum flux for our absorption line experiment, we request 2.8 arcsec as the largest angular scale. The angular resolution of 0.2 arcsec is chosen given the array configurations where the requested largest angular scale is achievable. Additionally, 0.2 arcsec resolution enables the study of about 30 AU size scales in the background disks for the secondary goals of our proposal.

For this absorption line experiment we are targeting continuum level signal-to-noise ratios (quoted as spectral dynamic range by the AOT) of about 20, such that 25% deep absorption features are detected at 5 times the RMS sensitivity level. Given this goal, peak line flux densities in the Field Setup are reported as 0.25 times the peak continuum flux densities. The achieved continuum level S/N depends on the flux of the background source at 893 GHz, which is estimated in the "source properties" field from reported 350 micron fluxes or spectral energy distributions (SED). An RMS level of 141 mJy will give continuum level S/N of about 20 for SR21(A) and 37 for Elia2-24. We can also bin channels to 0.33 km/s resolution to reduce the RMS to 100 mJy, and increase continuum level S/N to about 28 for SR21(A) and 52 for Elia 2-24 to search for weaker absorption features.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Dense molecular clouds consist of various layers, with physical conditions (e.g., density, temperature, radiation field) largely controlled by visual extinction to the cloud surface. In each region the chemistry is dominated by different mechanisms, and transitions between these layers are often marked by abrupt changes in molecular abundances. One such transition is that where water ice formation begins on grains, and models predict that the photodesorption of this water ice generates the observed gas-phase water abundances in dense clouds. The water column density as a function of total visual extinction through a cloud is expected to increase rapidly following ice formation, increase linearly throughout the photodesorption layer, and remain constant for larger extinctions. We will test this chemical model by measuring HDO column densities in a sample of dense clouds with a wide range of visual extinctions, using sub-mm bright protoplanetary disks embedded within the rho Oph molecular cloud as background continuum sources for an absorption line experiment.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
